book.title: De iuris arte, methodo, et praeceptis

marginalia.translation:
Grammar. 1. External or by speech. { } Style General or common. { Rhetoric. 2. Form [of Digest] { Internal or by reason. { Logic. 3. } Method
Special or particular.{ Nomological or legal. { The law itself, its soul, reason. 4. { that which is to be deliberated. that which is to be settled.
1.2. Lorenzo Valla wonderfully praises the style in the preface of the third book of the 'Elegancies'. 3. Pierre Gregoire, Doctor of Canon and Civil Law, examines and discusses the method in chapter two of 'De iuris arte, methodo, et praeceptis.' There it follows, generally speaking, this same order. And certainly we can defend the order of the body of the Digest in some manner, but not with that belief that it is arranged arbitrarily. Indeed, many things can (and should) be arranged more appropriately than as they are placed here, however after taking into account the traditional order made by those who stitched together the law. Add here the judgement of Dr Thomas Smith in the 'Legal Preface'.
Likewise, Francois Douaren, book one of 'Disputationum anniversariarum libri duo', chapter 55, where he agrees with the order and method of the 'Digest', refuting the innovators, who busy themselves with amending this method.
